journal-meta.journal-title: The American Journal of Sports Medicine

title-group.article-title: Influence of Sex on the Outcome of Autologous Chondrocyte Implantation in Chondral Defects of the Knee

article-meta.aff: †Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, University Medical Center Rostock, Rostock, Germany
‡Department of Trauma Surgery, University Hospital Basel, Basel, Switzerland

author-notes.corresp: *Peter C. Kreuz, Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, University Medical Center Rostock, Doberanerstr. 142, 18057 Rostock, Germany (e-mail: peter.kreuz@uni-rostock.de).

fn.p: Drs Kreuz and Müller contributed equally to this article.

permissions.copyright-holder: American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Sex-specific outcomes have been reported in anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction as well as in osteoarthrosis progression, but there are currently no related published data on autologous chondrocyte implantation (ACI). The present prospective study was performed to investigate sex-dependent differences in the results after ACI.

sec.title: Hypothesis:
sec.p: The clinical and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) results after ACI of the knee are influenced by the patient’s sex.

sec.title: Study Design:
sec.p: Cohort study; Level of evidence, 2.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: The midterm clinical and MRI results of a cell-based fibrin-polymer graft for the treatment of full-thickness cartilage defects were evaluated preoperatively and 6, 12, and 48 months after surgery in 52 patients (male:female ratio, 25:27; average age, 35.6 years). Depending on the sex and the location of the defects (femoral condyles, n = 32; patellofemoral compartment, n = 20), patients were assigned to 4 different groups. Baseline clinical scores were compared with follow-up data by paired Wilcoxon tests for the Lysholm score and the International Knee Documentation Committee (IKDC) scoring system. Sex-specific differences were evaluated with the Mann-Whitney U test. The MRI evaluation was performed with the Henderson score at final follow-up.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Clinical scores improved in all groups over the whole study period (P < .05). Compared with female patients, male patients achieved significantly better results in the Lysholm score at all time intervals and in the IKDC score at 6 and 12 months after surgery (P < .05). In a subgroup analysis, female patients with patellar defects had the worst results in both clinical scores. With the available number of patients, MRI evaluation at 48 months after surgery revealed no significant difference in defect fill between male and female patients (P > .05). The Pearson correlation coefficient between both clinical scores and the MRI parameters of defect fill and cartilage signal was significant (P < .05).

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: Autologous chondrocyte implantation is a promising treatment option for full-thickness cartilage defects of male and female knee joints. Female patients with patellar defects have worse prognostic factors.

body.p: Articular cartilage lesions have a limited capacity for spontaneous regeneration and are often associated with disability and symptoms such as joint pain, locking phenomena, and reduced function. The progression to osteoarthrosis is proven.1,4,16

Different surgical interventions including microfracture,17,26,37,39 mosaicplasty,13 or regenerative approaches such as autologous chondrocyte implantation (ACI)2,3,34,40 aim to restore pain-free joint function by promoting the formation of a new repair tissue. Autologous chondrocyte implantation has been established over the past 2 decades as a safe and effective treatment for large chondral and osteochondral defects of the knee joint.10,34 Peterson et al34 have reported greater than 70% good to excellent results in the only long-term analysis of first-generation ACI, even though this technique applied periosteum as a cover for the defect, which has been found to result in a higher incidence of delamination, calcification, insufficient bonding, and tissue hypertrophy.25 Today, advanced generations of ACI try to avoid these disadvantages of periosteum by using biocompatible cell carriers such as collagen hydrogels36 or membranes,40 a copolymer of polyglycolic/polylactic acid and polydioxanone,24 and hyaluronic acid as a vehicle for the chondrocytes.22 In some studies, these techniques have shown significant superior results compared with microfracture in large chondral lesions.21,35,41 Recent studies have been able to demonstrate improvement of the outcome of ACI by addressing independent variables, that is, concomitant injuries31; however, very few have evaluated the influence of dependent variables, such as sex.

Sex-dependent results have been reported but not discussed as a potential specific phenomenon of ACI.11,20,36,41 Differences in muscle forces, neuromuscular coordination, and hormonal influences on chondrogenic differentiation between men and women might support these results.9,19,32,45 The present prospective study was performed to investigate sex-dependent differences in clinical and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) outcomes after ACI.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: Seventy-nine patients with full-thickness chondral defects of the knee underwent ACI with a cell-based fibrin-polymer graft (BioSeed C; BioTissue Technologies GmbH, Freiburg, Germany).7 Thereof, 52 patients with an average age of 35.6 years (range, 18-51 years) and a body mass index of 25.0 kg/m2 met our inclusion criteria (below) and were enrolled in our prospective database. Depending on the sex (25 female, 27 male) and the location of the defects (femoral condyles or patellofemoral compartment), the patients were assigned to 4 different groups. The details appear in Table 1.

caption.p: Preoperative Patient Information in 52 Knees With Full-Thickness Cartilage Lesionsa

fn.label: a
fn.p: Values are expressed as mean ± standard deviation. Lesions were International Cartilage Repair Society grades 3B and 3C. Patients were assigned to 4 different main groups depending on sex and defect localization. There were no significant differences regarding the patient’s age and body mass index between the 4 groups (P > .05). The defect size on the femoral condyles and in the patellofemoral compartment was significantly higher in men compared with women (P < .05). There is no standard deviation given for the lateral femoral condyle for women because there was only 1 woman with a chondral defect on this location.

sec.title: Inclusion Criteria
sec.p: Clinical indications for surgery were symptomatic chondral lesions of the knee, which were verified on preoperative MRI. The inclusion criteria were full-thickness chondral defects of grade 3B to 3C according to the International Cartilage Repair Society (ICRS) classification system,18 which includes lesions extending down to the calcified layer (3B) but not through the subchondral bone plate (3C). The lesions were ≥2 cm2 in size and had to be located in only 1 of the 3 knee compartments (medial femorotibial joint, lateral femorotibial joint, or femoropatellar joint). Furthermore, the study population was limited to patients between 18 and 55 years of age.

sec.title: Exclusion Criteria
sec.p: Excluded were patients with acute trauma, limits in knee extension or flexion of <130°, varus or valgus deformities of >5°, instabilities of the collateral or cruciate ligaments, meniscal tears, osteochondral defects, drug treatment for osteoarthritis, or intra-articular corticosteroid injections within the previous month. Furthermore, we excluded patients with a tibial tubercle–trochlear groove (TT-TG) distance of >15 mm and those with patellar malalignment with a medial or lateral shift of >0.5 cm during the index arthroscopic examination.

sec.title: Study Design
sec.p: The prospective study with a 48-month follow-up was performed to investigate sex-dependent differences in the results after ACI. The study is based on scores with a continuous objective patient evaluation including control MRI over a period of 48 months. Approval was provided by the institutional review board, and informed consent was obtained from each patient.

sec.title: Study Course
sec.p: Each patient underwent the same standardized evaluation process preoperatively, intraoperatively, and postoperatively using the International Knee Documentation Committee (IKDC) examination form and the Lysholm score.18,28 Patients had to complete standardized questionnaires and were examined by an orthopaedic surgeon preoperatively and 6, 12, and 48 months after surgery. Varus or valgus deformities were evaluated by standing long leg radiographs. The correct patellar position was detected as described above. Furthermore, MRI (Sonata, Siemens, Erlangen, Germany) was performed preoperatively and 48 months (range, 45-50 months) after the surgical intervention, using a standard flexible knee coil and the following MRI sequences: T2-weighted fat-saturated coronal fast spin echo sequences, T1-weighted spin echo sequences, proton density–weighted sagittal spin echo sequences, and T2-weighted fat-saturated sagittal gradient-echo sequences (dual-echo steady state). Slice thickness of all mentioned sequences was 3 mm, with the exception of the gradient-echo sequence (1 mm). According to the classification system of Henderson et al,14 the following 4 criteria were evaluated: defect filling (1 = complete; 2 = ≥50% of the defect; 3 = <50% of the defect; 4 = full-thickness defect), cartilage signal (1 = normal, identical to the adjacent articular cartilage; 2 = nearly normal, slight areas of hyperintensity; 3 = abnormal, larger areas of hyperintensity; 4 = absent), and subchondral edema and effusion (both graded as 1 = absent; 2 = mild; 3 = moderate; 4 = severe). The overall MRI score corresponded to the worst score in the 4 categories. The amount of fill reflects the growth of repair tissue; the signal might be an indicator of maturity of the graft. Especially in comparison with the signal of the adjacent normal cartilage, effusion is an indicator for chronic irritation or infection of the joint, and the subchondral edema might reflect the attachment to the underlying bone, cartilage tears, and the process of graft remodeling.14

sec.title: Treatment
sec.p: The ACI procedure consists of a cartilage biopsy specimen, which is harvested from the area of unstressed cartilage in the region of the intercondylar fossa with a standard instrument set. There was 100 mL of blood collected (Sarstedt AG, Nümbrecht, Germany) for cell cultivation. Chondrocytes were expanded in vitro and rearranged 3-dimensionally in fibrin and a polymer-based scaffold of polyglycolic/polylactic acid (polyglactin, vicryl) and polydioxanone. In a second mini-open surgical procedure, the exposed bone was debrided of all remaining unstable cartilage to obtain a perpendicular edge of healthy well-attached viable cartilage surrounding the defect. The tissue-engineered graft was fitted to the size of the defect and implanted with transosseous fixation as reported previously.7 Repeated flexion and extension of the knee confirmed the stable fixation of the graft. The procedure was performed at one institution by a single surgeon.

Postoperative mobilization was started on the day after surgery with a continuous passive motion machine for 6 to 8 hours per day. For lesions on the weightbearing surfaces of the condyles, the initial range of motion increased as tolerated from full extension to 90° of flexion for 6 weeks after surgery. For lesions of the femoropatellar joint, flexion was limited to 30° with a brace for 2 weeks, to 60° for another 2 weeks, and to 90° until the sixth week after surgery. By limiting knee flexion, the brace prevents too much pressure on the soft tissue graft in patellofemoral chondral lesions in the early stages after surgery. Cold therapy was used for all patients for 1 week. Crutch-assisted, touchdown weightbearing ambulation was prescribed for 6 weeks after the surgical procedure. Afterward, the patients progressed to full weightbearing and began a more vigorous program of active motion of the knee. Crutch-free walking was permitted after 12 weeks, and return to sports was permitted depending on the clinical examination. Gentle exertion such as cycling or jogging was allowed after 4 months, and contact sports including jumping, cutting, or pivoting were avoided until at least 9 months.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Descriptive statistics during follow-up (arithmetic mean, standard deviation, range) were calculated using standard formulas. Baseline clinical scores were compared with follow-up data by paired Wilcoxon tests and Friedman tests for the Lysholm score and the IKDC score.

The effects of patient sex and localization of the defects were evaluated using the independent-samples Mann-Whitney U test. Furthermore, MRI characteristics and clinical scores were compared using the Pearson correlation coefficient. All statistics were performed with SPSS version 18 (SPSS Inc, Chicago, Illinois) and reviewed by an independent statistician. Differences were considered significant at P < .05.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The index arthroscopic examination during biopsy confirmed no patellofemoral malalignment and no patellar shift to the medial or lateral trochlea facets in all patients. All chondral defects were full-thickness lesions and diffuse on the patella as well as on the trochlea, extending from the center to its medial and lateral facets. All groups showed a significant improvement in both scores over the whole study period (P < .02) (Tables 2 and 3). Furthermore, all 4 subgroups improved continuously over 48 months after surgery. However, improvement between 12 and 48 months was no longer significant (P >.15) in the Lysholm score for all subgroups and in the IKDC score for female femoral condyles and male patellofemoral compartments (Table 2). After 48 months, defect location did not influence the clinical results within the male study group (P > .87). In the female group, patients with defects in the patellofemoral compartment had significantly worse results than patients with defects on the femoral condyles (P < .05). Male patients had better values than female patients in both scores at any time of follow-up. Significant differences could be detected in the IKDC score (P < .05) after 6 and 12 months and in the Lysholm score (P < .03) at all time intervals after surgery (Table 3).

caption.p: IKDC and Lysholm Scores Preoperatively and 6, 12, and 48 Months After Autologous Chondrocyte Implantationa

tr.td: Mann-Whitney U test between subgroups after 48 mo
Mann-Whitney U test between subgroups after 48 mo

fn.label: a
fn.p: Values are expressed as mean ± standard deviation. IKDC, International Knee Documentation Committee.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Significant improvement (P < .02) compared with the last time period. All groups improved over the whole study period (P < .02). In both scores, all patients improved most within the first 6 months after surgery (P < .02). Between 12 and 48 months postoperatively, there was no more significant improvement (P > .1) in women’s femoral condyles and men’s patellofemoral compartment in the IKDC score and in all groups in the Lysholm score. After 48 months, male patients had the best results. Women with defects in the patellofemoral compartment reached the lowest values in both scores (P < .05).

caption.p: Sex-Dependent Differences in the IKDC and Lysholm Scores at Each Time Interval After Implantation of Bioseed Ca

tr.td: Mann-Whitney U test between male and female patients
Mann-Whitney U test between male and female patients

fn.label: a
fn.p: Values are expressed as mean ± standard deviation. IKDC, International Knee Documentation Committee.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Significant differences. All groups show a continuous improvement over the whole study period (P < .05). Male patients achieved better results at any time of follow-up. Significant differences (P < .05) could be detected in the IKCD score after 6 and 12 months and in the Lysholm score at all time intervals after surgery.

sec.p: After 12 and 48 months, the clinical results for patients with defects on the femoral condyles were independent of sex (P > .92). In contrast, female patients with defects in the patellofemoral compartment had significantly worse results after 12 and 48 months compared with male patients (P < .04) (Table 2). A more detailed subgroup analysis showed that female patients with patellar lesions had significantly worse results after 48 months than male patients (P < .04). No other statistically significant differences between other defect areas were detected because of the small numbers of patients within these subgroups. Furthermore, only female patients revealed significantly worse clinical scores after 48 months in patellar lesions compared with femoral lesions (P < .05). In male patients, the clinical scores were independent of defect area (Table 2).

Within the first year after ACI, 6 patients underwent second-look arthroscopic surgery as a result of symptoms such as persistent grinding, catching, pain, or swelling. The implanted grafts completely filled the defects and formed a tough hyaline-like cartilage (Figure 1). Revision included synovectomy (n = 5) and debridement (n = 1) of tissue hypertrophy.

caption.p: Diagnostic arthroscopic procedure at 12 months after autologous chondrocyte implantation with Bioseed C. The repair tissue has filled the former defect area and is well integrated to the surrounding articular cartilage.

sec.p: Magnetic resonance imaging at 48 months after surgery revealed the best defect fill in male patients (Figures 2 and 3); however, the difference to female patients was not significant (P > .08). The location of the cartilage defects did not influence the MRI results (P > .25) (Table 4).

caption.p: Sagittal T2-weighted magnetic resonance imaging study (repetition time, 22.54 ms; echo time, 6.06 ms) of a 32-year-old man. The image shows a huge full-thickness chondral defect on the medial femoral condyle with a small subchondral edema.

Sagittal T2-weighted magnetic resonance imaging study (repetition time, 22.54 ms; echo time, 6.06 ms) at 48 months after autologous chondrocyte implantation of the defect on the medial femoral condyle, as shown in Figure 2. The former cartilage lesion is completely filled.
MRI Results With the Henderson Classification at 48 Months After Surgerya

fn.label: a
fn.p: Values are expressed as mean ± standard deviation. Male patients with defects on the femoral condyles had the best results regarding defect filling. No significant differences could be found between subgroups. FC, femoral condyle; PF, patellofemoral compartment; MRI, magnetic resonance imaging.

sec.p: The Pearson correlation coefficient showed neither significant correlation between defect sizes and clinical outcome nor between defect location, sex, and clinical outcome (P > .05). However, there was a significant correlation between clinical and MRI scores (P < .05), specifically between both scores (Lysholm and IKDC) and the parameters of defect filling (r = 0.46) and cartilage signal (r = 0.38) in all patients. There was no significant correlation between clinical scores and the parameters of subchondral edema and effusion (P > .45).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In the present study, we compared the clinical and MRI outcomes in men and women after ACI on the femoral condyles and the patellofemoral compartment in the knee. We found better clinical results in men compared with women at all time intervals after surgery. The differences were significant in the IKDC score after 6 and 12 months and in the Lysholm score at 6, 12, and 48 months after surgery (P < .05).

Similar results have been reported in other clinical studies. Jungmann et al20 investigated 413 patients during a follow-up time of 2 to 11.8 years for individual and environmental risk factors for revision surgery after ACI of first and advanced generations. They found 4 prognostic factors associated with a significantly higher risk for reintervention including ACI with a periosteal membrane (P = .028), previous bone marrow stimulation (P = .041), previous surgeries on the affected joint (P = .002), and female sex (P = .033). Sex-specific results were also detected in a prospective study of Gille et al,11 which evaluated the autologous matrix-induced chondrogenesis procedure using a collagen I/III membrane for the treatment of focal cartilage defects of the knee. The ICRS score showed significantly better results at up to 36 months’ follow-up for male patients compared with their female counterparts in 27 patients with 23 chondral defects (P < .003). Another multicenter study investigated the clinical and MRI results after matrix-associated ACI with a 3-dimensional collagen type I hydrogel in 116 patients.36 They found a significant improvement in the IKDC score, SF-36 score, and pain level with a mean follow-up of 30.2 months after surgery. Specifically, their results pointed toward better outcome scores in men compared with women, but they were unable to perform a subgroup analysis comparing the location in each sex group (P < .05).36

Vanlauwe and his coworkers41 recently published their 5-year results of a randomized controlled trial comparing characterized chondrocyte implantation (51 patients) and microfracture (61 patients). Subgroup analysis revealed that ACI resulted in better outcomes in the Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS) score in participants with time since symptom onset of less than 3 years (P = .026). Age did not influence the clinical results, but female patients showed more failures irrespective of treatment. Male patients had to undergo fewer revision surgeries as compared with female patients; namely, 6 of 19 female patients versus 1 of 32 male patients failed ACI treatment (P = .007). In the microfracture group, the same trend was observed in which 7 of 20 female versus 3 of 41 male patients underwent reinterventions after ACI (P = .01).41

In contrast, there are a few studies that were unable to detect a significant difference in outcome scores or failure rate when analyzing the effect of sex. McNickle et al29 demonstrated that there were no sex-specific differences (P = .94) with the first-generation ACI in a cohort study with 122 patients and a follow-up of 4.3 years. However, their study population was heterogeneous with defect sizes ranging from 0.8 to 26.3 cm2.

Similar findings were published by Krishnan et al,27 who analyzed 199 patients after ACI with a collagen membrane with a 4-year follow-up. They found that sex did not significantly influence the clinical results (P = .20). However, the study population was heterogeneous as well, and single-factor analysis of variance (ANOVA) was performed while comparing nonnumerical variables between groups. In comparison with the report of Vanlauwe et al,41 Krishnan et al’s27 study had only few and weak inclusion criteria, such as patient’s age between 10 and 55 years and a defect size of >1 cm2. Further, ACI was performed in all defect locations, single and multiple lesions, chondral and osteochondral defects, with and without previous trauma and independent of the number of previous surgeries.27 The studies of Krishnan et al27 and McNickle et al29 are level IV case series, whereas the study of Vanlauwe et al41 is a level I study. The largest number of patients with the longest follow-up has been reported by Jungmann et al,20 with results that support the hypothesis of sex-specific outcome.

In the present study, we applied strict inclusion and exclusion criteria to study a homogeneous group of male and female patients. We included only patients without patellofemoral malalignment, which was controlled by measuring a TT-TG distance of <15 mm on preoperative MRI and during the index arthroscopic examination. Furthermore, there were no significant differences regarding patient age or body mass index (P > .05). We have found significantly higher outcome scores (P < . 05) in male compared with female patients, especially in patellar defects.

However, the total defect size was significantly larger in men compared with women (P < .05). Specifically, in the patellofemoral compartment, the defect size was on average 2.5 cm2 larger in male patients compared with female patients (P < .05). This finding is of particular importance because female patients with defects on the patella had the worst clinical outcome (P < .05).8 Female patients had significantly better outcome scores in femoral lesions compared with patellar lesions (P < .05). In male patients, the clinical scores were independent of defect localization (Table 2). Because patients with patellofemoral abnormalities and malalignment were excluded from our study population, we suggest that insufficient proprioception and imbalances in muscle forces could account for the worse results in female patients with defects in the patellofemoral compartment.

It is known that female athletes participating in high-risk sports suffer anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injuries at a 4- to 6-fold greater rate than do male athletes. It has mostly been attributed to sex differences in biomechanics of the knee joint.15,33 Additionally, it has been found that women reach about 70% of the muscle force of men,30 and torsional stiffness of the knee during loading tests in men is greater compared with women,12,46 which could lead to altered contact pressures. A recent study by Kreuz et al23 has supported this hypothesis by identifying lower isokinetic muscle strength in women undergoing the ACI procedure compared with men (P < .05). All these reports suggest that there is reduced knee joint stabilization in the female knee joint that would be necessary for the protection of the newly formed chondral tissue in women during regeneration and maturation. Other authors have suggested that neurocognitive performance and postural stability are markedly impaired after injuries such as concussion: female patients were found to take a longer time to recuperate and regain full neurocognitive performance than were male patients (P < .05).5 We hypothesize that once that neuromuscular axis has been disrupted either because of an injury to the brain or to the proprioceptive apparatus of a joint, female patients take longer to restore the original biomechanics and exercise the physiology. Smith et al38 have found that male patients returned to sports at a significantly higher percentage after ACL reconstruction when compared with female patients (P < .02). This is likely to be applicable to other procedures such as cartilage repair techniques in which prolonged deconditioning of the neuromuscular axis is observed.23

Apart from the physiological differences, several others have reported on anatomic differences between female and male sex. Faber et al8 compared cartilage thickness, volume, and articular surface areas in nonathletic healthy male and female participants using MRI and found that women displayed smaller cartilage volumes than men. The percentage difference ranged from 19.9% in the patella to 46.6% in the medial tibia between the 2 sexes. In a recent sequence of biomechanical studies, sex differences with respect to joint kinematics were reported.42-44 Varadarajan et al44 studied 13 female and 18 male patients performing lunges and assessed patellar tracking and tibial rotation with dual fluoroscopy and MRI and found that normal healthy female participants demonstrated significant differences in patellar orientation and tracking compared with male patients as well as tibiofemoral rotation at low flexion angles. This altered biomechanical characteristic might alter contact pressures in the patellofemoral compartment, leading to worse outcomes in cartilage repair restoration.6

Further studies are required to investigate a possible correlation between sex-specific clinical results, defect location, and biomechanical data including muscle force measurement. This could potentially lead to an individualized rehabilitation program as well as treatment algorithm for female patients. This is the first prospective study with a special focus on sex-specific differences after ACI of chondral defects in the knee measured by continuous objective patient evaluation over 48 months including clinical and MRI scores.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The clinical results after ACI with a cell-based fibrin-polymer graft of ICRS grade 3B and 3C lesions in the knee are sex dependent. Male patients with defects on the femoral condyles have the best prognostic factors.

fn.p: The authors declared that they have no conflicts of interest in the authorship and publication of this contribution.
